H0.text: Migrating to habitats that had different types of crops allowed the surviving insects, after most were killed by DDT in the 1970s, to increase their population in fruit and vegetable crop areas.

H1.text: Learning how to avoid being exposed to DDT is how the surviving insects contributed to an increase in their population in the 1970s, when the pesticide DDT was used to kill insects that damaged fruit and vegetable crops, with most insects dying from exposure but some surviving.

H2.text: Passing the gene for DDT resistance to their offspring was how the surviving insects contributed to an increase in their population during the 1970s when DDT was used to kill insects that damaged fruit and vegetable crops.

H3.text: Competing with other types of insects for food contributed to an increase in the surviving insect population after the widespread use of DDT in the 1970s to kill insects damaging fruit and vegetable crops.

A4.text: Insects with certain mutations in their sodium channel gene are resistant to DDT and similar insecticides. DDT resistance is also conferred by up-regulation of genes expressing cytochrome P450 in some insect species, as greater quantities of some enzymes of this group accelerate the toxin's metabolism into inactive metabolites.
